data.message: The Met Breuer was named the “Best Museum for New Yorkers” in Village Voice’s “Best of NYC” issue.
data.name: Best Museum for New Yorkers: The Met Breuer
data.caption: villagevoice.com
data.description: Like any jilted fifty-year-old who has taken a new lover, the building now known as the Met Breuer has a new mojo.

data.message: Delighted to hear this. Congrats, Thomas P. Campbell, Carrie Barratt, Sheila Wagstaff, Amy Romero, Joe Shatoff, Warren Bruce - and everyone!

I had a most delightful encounter with some school children at the Diane Arbus photography exhibit yesterday. They pulled me from one photograph to another, asking questions, & I hope I helped them to understand the images better. Good display of her work!

Now if you would only go back to the drawing boards on the new logo... hoo boy, that's a klunker.
(*coming from a Manhattan native, lifeling NYCer, art school kid [HS of Art & Design '83], artist & designer [yes, graphic design, old & new school]). My earliest memory of life is being 3 years old at the Met in the Egyptian wing, and ascending the great staircase... in HS, we used to cut out and go uptown to the Met, budding young artist-cool kids we were... anywayyyy, my informal poll of fellow native NYer/designers unanimously agree -- GONG!! No shame in failure, please try again.
I am eager to see if the Met will finally take modern and contemporary art seriously. The NY Times had an interesting article on it in the spring. I always loved this space. Classic Bauhaus.

from.name: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York

data.message:
The Costume Institute's spring 2017 exhibition will examine the work of Japanese fashion designer Rei Kawakubo. http://met.org/2ePhrnH

"Rei Kawakubo/Comme des Garçons" will feature approximately 120 examples of Kawakubo’s womenswear for Comme des Garçons, from her first Paris runway show in 1981 to her most recent collection.

The thematic show, on view from May 4 to September 4, will be The Costume Institute’s first monographic show on a living designer since the Yves Saint Laurent exhibition in 1983.
data.name: What the Comme des Garçons Show Means for the Met — and Fashion
data.caption: nytimes.com
data.description: Rei Kawakubo will be only the second living designer ever recognized with a solo show at the Costume Institute, a potentially game-changing decision.

data.message: WOW!!!  When I studied at FIDM in the 80's, Kawakubo was all-the-rage amongst the couture klatsch, natch.  We saw the 2014 Gaultier exhibition in Melbourne, and (perhaps) this one may rival (if not surpass) that one...!  :D

data.message: “['Max Beckmann in New York’] the best show I’ve seen anywhere in New York this year.”—The New York Times
data.name: Review: ‘Max Beckmann in New York,’ a Belated but Full-Blown Homage to a German Modernist
data.caption: nytimes.com
data.description: There’s not a single dud among the 39 works in a show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art about this Expressionist painter’s special connection to the city.

data.message: Beckmann had been in St.Louis a little while and I was quite young when I started visiting the Morton May collection of Beckman in City Art Museum (now Saint Louis Art Museum). I grew up with his images always on my mind. Oh my God, what a heady childhood. Visiting this show will be the pinnacle of my life in Art. Although visiting the fragile "The Studio" in conservation at Saint Louis Art Museum when I worked there. It is masterful and more spare.

I am presenting at the American Indian Science and Engineering Society's National Conference in Minneapolis coming November. Here is my accepted abstract.
Donald Belile
Presenter Status: PhD
Presentation Type: Oral Presentation
BIO:
Donald Belile originates from the Pine Ridge Reservation in southwestern SD and is an enrolled member of the Oglala Lakota Sioux. Mr. Belile has a B.S. in Interdisciplinary Environmental Science, M.S. in Systems and is currently attending The University of Montana while working toward a PhD in Systems Ecology under the guidance of Dr. Ragan Callaway. Key interests of Mr. Belile are in working with buffalo (Bison bison) and Tribes in the United States and Canada.
Session Title: Estimating Buffalo (Bison bison) Ecological Carrying Capacity Across Varying Temporal and Spatial Scales in Montana
Co-Authors: Dr. Ragan Callaway, Ecologist at The University of Montana
Session Abstract:
Wildlife managers, ranchers and scientists can agree that it is difficult to estimate how many buffalo (Bison bison) the landscape can support without risk of over grazing and ensuing ecological degradation. My PhD research is to use GIS and remote sensing products to perform a spatio-temporal analysis of bison impacts across every landscape inhabited by bison in Montana currently and in the near past, and for the entire length of the Landsat imagery legacy dataset using NASA intelligence within Google Earth Engine, executed in Java script. Disturbance of phenological plant cycles and changes to the underlying soil base are key components to understanding ecosystem tipping points as is the consideration of the interspecific interactions and pressure that over grazing directly or indirectly exerts on other wildlife. Bottom-up and top-down trophic relationships vary over space and time, and the impacts of these bidirectional interactions can be intensified by global warming. Mechanistic ecosystem modeling can be calibrated with ground data and informed with geospatial datasets over time to predict grazing impacts and primary productivity. Scientific based decision support can translate into improved herd fitness, help maintain Native American cultural integrity, and provide sustanence for the entire U.S. in the near future. A statistical based buffalo ecological carrying capacity model is fundamental in managing buffalo in North America.

from.name: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York

data.message: Happy Birthday to Dutch landscape painter Aelbert Cuyp, born on this day in 1620. Cuyp was the most talented member of a family of painters from Dordrecht, where city dwellers entertained idyllic notions of life on the land. In this sun-blessed landscape under satiny clouds, cows sit around like sofas on a carpet of grass and the three figures appear to discuss nothing more urgent than which way they might take an afternoon stroll.
data.name: Featured Artwork of the Day
data.caption: metmuseum.org
data.description: Aelbert Cuyp (Dutch, 1620–1691) | Young Herdsmen with Cows | The Met

data.message: Love Aelbert Cuyp's views . . . . lots of depth, elegant space, the interaction of near and far . . . . people usually transitory and so much a part of things . . . . the nobility of cows
Cuyp would have been hard pressed to find a landscape anything like that in Holland, and certainly nowhere near Dordrecht. Idyllic and Idealised indeed.

Howard, what a wonderful painting! Do you ever go into the city to see these wonderful paintings at the MET? To see them in person is so alive. Going to the city is not what it used to be however, at least from my perspective!
My favorite Cuyp painting has windmills, cows, and sail boats. And a big sky, of course.
One of my favorites! Someone at the museum told me one pronounces it "cowp," like the cows he paints.
I can easily see where American, Hudson River school, Thomas Hewes Hinckley gained inspiration, technique & style.

from.name: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York

data.message:
The #MetonPaper100 “Work of the Week” is Altdorfer's landscape with Samson and Delilah in the foreground. This autonomous drawing on colored ground has fine pen work that is characteristic of his early drawings.

To celebrate the centenary of the founding of the Department of Drawings and Prints, gallery 690 is featuring one masterpiece per week through April 30, 2017. View "Samson and Delilah" before next Monday.

Albrecht Altdorfer (German, ca. 1480–1538) | Samson and Delilah | 1506 http://met.org/2ej427F

from.name: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York

data.message: Celebrate the birthday of futurist painter and sculptor Umberto Boccioni with today’s Featured Artwork of the Day. Rather than delineating the contours of his subject, a bottle, he integrated the object’s internal and external spatial planes, which appear to unfold and spiral into surrounding space.
data.name: Featured Artwork of the Day
data.caption: metmuseum.org
data.description: Umberto Boccioni (Italian, 1882–1916) | Development of a Bottle in Space | The Met

data.message: I love Boccioni's sculptures! Thanks #themet!
Very bold and futuristic,mathematics and geometry genius,shines!

from.name: Aristos (An Online Review of the Arts)

data.message: No one would think of a "bottle" just by viewing "Development of a Bottle in Space." The idea might be interesting, but the piece is not art. - Louis Torres, Co-Editor, Aristos (An Online Review of the Arts), and Co-Author, ‘What Art Is: The Esthetic Theory of Ayn Rand’ (Open Court, 2000) - http://www.aristos.org

Watch live as Alina Cho and Olivier Rousteing, Creative Director of Balmain, discuss the fashionworld at the intersection of art and ideas.

Part of “The Atelier with Alina Cho” series, this conversation will cover a variety of topics, including Rousteing’s career and how he revived Balmain, relying on the house's tradition of artisanal excellence while creating a new modern silhouette and offerings for Balmain's diverse, young "army." http://met.org/2einahj #OlivierxTheMet #AtelierAlinaCho #MetSpeaks

data.message: The Bering Sea Eskimo were careful to decorate the tools with which they hunted. The beautifully balanced and elegantly incised objects were functional tools that were incised with spirit images and designs that honored the animals the hunters sought.
data.name: Harpoon Head | Old Bering Sea | The Met
data.caption: metmuseum.org

data.message: Diseño exquisito y gratitud hacia los animales que nos dan de comer. ¿Hemos evolucionado algo en ese aspecto? Creo que más bien hemos retrocedido.

data.message:
This afternoon we’re at the studio of artist Jean Shin with #MetTeens volunteer Omega Nugent. 

During today’s interview, Jean and Omega will discuss a collaborative art installation Jean is planning with The Met and Materials for the Arts. Teens 13+ can create this slide art installation with Jean on Friday, October 28 at 5–8 pm during Teens Take The Met! (Ages 13–18)—an event filled with teen-only activities, performances, a dance party, and more that we do in collaboration with over 40 cultural and community partners.

from.name: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York

data.message: Childe Hassam, a pioneer of American Impressionism and perhaps its most devoted, prolific, and successful practitioner, was born on this day in 1859. This intimate landscape, with its strong rhythmic composition, flattened space, and tapestry-like application of paint, illustrates the modification of Hassam's style at the turn of the century. Learn more and view a slideshow of his works: http://met.org/2aM64vC
data.name: Childe Hassam (American, 1859–1935) | The Water Garden | The Met
data.caption: metmuseum.org

data.message: I had to go to Wikipedia for more!  I especially like the flag series, which must have been the first of his works I saw in a textbook. I'm glad I pursued the subject and found so many other images.
Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, MA, has a very nice exhibit of Hassan's paintings from his times on Appledore (Isles of Shoals) until Nov. 6.

from.name: Aristos (An Online Review of the Arts)

data.message: Hassam [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Childe_Hassam] is a great painter who deserves even greater public recognition than he already enjoys. Here are images of 696[!] of his works [http://www.the-athenaeum.org/art/list.php?s=yu&m=a&aid=1310]. - Louis Torres, Co-Editor, Aristos (An Online Review of the Arts) - http://www.aristos.org
Childe Hassam is one of my favorite American Impressionists, I particularly love his NY City winter street paintings
One of my favorite paintings at the Des Moines Art Center is a Childe Hassam.
love this, had no idea of this artist and very little knowledge of American Impressionism.Truly inspiring.
Love the inviting atmosphere. Also like Surf, Isles of Shoals. What coloring! Both are absolutely soothing and breath taking. http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/works-of-art/1996.382/
I saw his exhibit when he was in Raleigh a few months ago.beautiful work..
More luminous than the noted impressionists. This is almost three dimensional.
The MFA is also featuring Hassam today.  Wonderful artist.
wow, did I need to gaze at this painting today!
He painted the extraordinary light in Hamptons and Maine..An Island Garden...Visited and hooked a rug in his style. Indeed an American treasure
One of my favorite artists.  So glad my family and I got to see the flag series at the Met years ago.
Is that Pre-Raphaelite? I love Pre-Rapaelites! But of course I also have no taste in art. Just ask anyone.

from.name: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York

data.message: Happy birthday to author, playwright and poet Oscar Wilde, born on this day in 1854. Napoleon Sarony took photographs of Wilde when he came to America in 1882 to give a series of lectures on the English Renaissance. In this photograph, Wilde leans toward the viewer as though engaging him in dialogue, the appearance and calculated pose of the dandy secondary to the intelligence and spontaneous charm of the conversationalist.
data.name: Featured Artwork of the Day
data.caption: metmuseum.org
data.description: Napoleon Sarony (American (born Canada), 1821–1896) | Oscar Wilde | The Met

data.message: Many weren't aware that Oscar Wilde even had children, a son for one. That my friend here in this picture once dated. She was 100 years old last year, born in, England..

And the case Burrow-Giles Lithographic Co. v. Sarony, 111 U.S. 53, decided by the Supreme Court of the United States upheld the power of Congress to extend copyright protection to photography—based on this photograph.
